Authors: Susanto R., Wiedjaja, Anthony J., Jacksen
Title: Comparison of three LoRa devices and its application on street light monitoring system
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Computer Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Susanto, R., Computer Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Wiedjaja, Computer Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Anthony, J., Computer Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Jacksen, Computer Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: This paper discusses implementation of Long Range (LoRa) networks as an Internet of Things (IoT) objects especially on street light monitoring. Low Powered Wide Area Network (LPWAN) is used as a communication network. LoRa devices are configured with a frequency of 470 MHz, spread factor 9, bandwidth of 31.25 KHz, and code rate of 4/5. The study found that the UM402 LoRa module has the farthest network range, up to 1 Km. By focusing on a range of up to 250 m, the LoRa Dragino shield has the fastest data packet delivery time at 0.77 s. UM402 LoRa module has the largest Received Signal Strength Indication (RSSI) value at 50m, it is -34. All LoRa devices used in this research can operate well at the ideal distance of street lights (35 m). © 2018 Institute of Physics Publishing. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: dan Low Powered Wide Area Network; Internet of Things; Long Range
Index Keywords: Internet of things; Low power electronics; Data packet delivery; Internet of Things (IOT); ITS applications; Light monitoring; Long Range; Network range; Received signal strength indication; Spread factors; Wide area networks
